title: Cigarette holder
text:
A cigarette holder is a <a href="fashion%20accessory">fashion accessory</a>, a slender tube in which a <a href="cigarette">cigarette</a> is held for <a href="Tobacco%20smoking">smoking</a>. Most frequently made of <a href="silver">silver</a>, <a href="jade">jade</a> or <a href="bakelite">bakelite</a> (popular in the past but now wholly replaced by modern plastics), cigarette holders were considered an essential part of ladies' <a href="fashion">fashion</a> from the early 1910s through early to the mid 1970s.
Purpose.
The holder was a practical accessory and served several purposes:
In 1997, <a href="Philip%20Morris%20International">Philip Morris</a> tested a new battery-powered cigarette holder that completely eliminated cigarette smoke.
Appearance.
Materials.
Cigarette holders range from the simplest, single-material constructs to incredibly ornate objects with complex inlays of metal and gemstones. Rarer examples of these can be found in <a href="Vitreous%20enamel">enamel</a>, <a href="horn%20%28anatomy%29">horn</a>, <a href="tortoiseshell">tortoiseshell</a>, or more precious materials such as <a href="amber">amber</a> and <a href="ivory">ivory</a>.
A similar holder made of <a href="wood">wood</a>, <a href="meerschaum">meerschaum</a> or <a href="bakelite">bakelite</a> and with an <a href="amber">amber</a> mouthpiece was used for <a href="cigar">cigar</a>s and was a popular accessory for men from the <a href="Edwardian">Edwardian</a> period until the 1920s.
Size.
As with <a href="evening%20gloves">evening gloves</a>, ladies' cigarette holders are measured by four traditional formal standard lengths:
Traditionally, men's cigarette holders were no more than 4 inches long.
Notable users.
Well-known women who used cigarette holders include <a href="Audrey%20Hepburn">Audrey Hepburn</a>, <a href="Lucille%20Ball">Lucille Ball</a>, <a href="Jayne%20Mansfield">Jayne Mansfield</a>, <a href="Jacqueline%20Kennedy">Jacqueline Kennedy</a>, <a href="Rita%20Hayworth">Rita Hayworth</a>, <a href="Princess%20Margaret">Princess Margaret</a>, <a href="Wendy%20Richard">Wendy Richard</a>, <a href="Madalena%20Barbosa">Madalena Barbosa</a>, <a href="Natalie%20Wood">Natalie Wood</a>, <a href="Louise%20Brooks">Louise Brooks</a>, and <a href="Ayn%20Rand">Ayn Rand</a>. <a href="Scarlett%20Johansson">Scarlett Johansson</a> is a contemporary example.
Among the best-known men who used cigarette holders were <a href="Franklin%20D.%20Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a>, <a href="Ivor%20Novello">Ivor Novello</a>, <a href="Enrico%20Caruso">Enrico Caruso</a>, <a href="Vladimir%20Horowitz">Vladimir Horowitz</a>, <a href="Ian%20Fleming">Ian Fleming</a>, <a href="No%C3%ABl%20Coward">Noël Coward</a>, <a href="Hunter%20S.%20Thompson">Hunter S. Thompson</a> (though he regarded his as only a filter), <a href="Tennessee%20Williams">Tennessee Williams</a>, <a href="Fulgencio%20Batista">Fulgencio Batista</a>, <a href="Sergei%20Rachmaninoff">Sergei Rachmaninoff</a>, <a href="Josip%20Broz%20Tito">Josip Broz Tito</a>, and <a href="Hans%20von%20B%C3%BClow">Hans von Bülow</a>.
Cultural references.
Holders can be seen in period films like "<a href="Titanic%20%281997%20film%29">Titanic</a>", and in films of the 1950s and 1960s. Holly Golightly, the naïve and eccentric <a href="caf%C3%A9%20society">café society</a> girl portrayed by <a href="Audrey%20Hepburn">Audrey Hepburn</a> in the 1961 classic "<a href="Breakfast%20at%20Tiffany%27s%20%28film%29">Breakfast at Tiffany's</a>", is famously seen carrying an oversized cigarette holder; the image of Hepburn wearing the famous <a href="Givenchy">Givenchy</a> <a href="Black%20Givenchy%20dress%20of%20Audrey%20Hepburn">little black dress</a> and with the foot-long cigarette holder in her hand, is considered one of the most iconic images of 20th-century <a href="Cinema%20of%20the%20United%20States">American cinema</a>. <a href="Lucille%20Ball">Lucille Ball</a> can be seen using one in certain episodes of "<a href="I%20Love%20Lucy">I Love Lucy</a>". In "<a href="Troop%20Beverly%20Hills">Troop Beverly Hills</a>", Shelly Long's character is seen throughout the movie using one. <a href="Cruella%20de%20Vil">Cruella de Vil</a> is seen using one repeatedly in the 1961 animated <a href="Disney">Disney</a> film "<a href="One%20Hundred%20and%20One%20Dalmatians">One Hundred and One Dalmatians</a>" and in the 1996 remake, in which she is portrayed by <a href="Glenn%20Close">Glenn Close</a>. <a href="Margo%20Lane">Margo Lane</a> (portrayed by <a href="Penelope%20Ann%20Miller">Penelope Ann Miller</a>) used one in "<a href="The%20Shadow%20%281994%20film%29">The Shadow</a>", as did <a href="Jonny%20Quest%23Characters">Jade</a> in "Jonny Quest". Comedian <a href="Phyllis%20Diller">Phyllis Diller</a> had a stage persona which included holding a long cigarette holder from which she pretended to smoke (though she was a non-smoker in real life).
Fictional "<a href="Peter%20Pan">Peter Pan</a>" character <a href="Captain%20Hook">Captain Hook</a> possessed a unique double-holder, which allowed him to smoke two cigars (not cigarettes) at once. 
<a href="Batman">Batman</a>'s nemesis <a href="The%20Penguin">The Penguin</a> also commonly uses a cigarette holder in the <a href="comics">comics</a>, the <a href="Batman%20%28TV%20series%29">1960s television series</a>, the live-action film "<a href="Batman%20Returns">Batman Returns</a>", "", and "<a href="Harley%20Quinn%20%28TV%20series%29">Harley Quinn</a>". <a href="Edna%20Mode">Edna Mode</a> from <a href="The%20Incredibles%20%28franchise%29">the Incredibles franchise</a> is often seen with an unlit cigarette holder.
<a href="Johnny%20Depp">Johnny Depp</a> uses a cigarette holder in his role as <a href="Raoul%20Duke">Raoul Duke</a> (alter ego of gonzo journalist Hunter S. Thompson) in the film "<a href="Fear%20and%20Loathing%20in%20Las%20Vegas%20%28film%29">Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas</a>". In <a href="cartoon">cartoon</a>s, the <a href="Pink%20Panther%20%28character%29">Pink Panther</a>, <a href="Colonel%20Sponsz">Colonel Sponsz</a> from "<a href="The%20Adventures%20of%20Tintin">The Adventures of Tintin</a>", and Jade from "<a href="Jonny%20Quest">Jonny Quest</a>" use cigarette holders.
The lyrics to "<a href="Satin%20Doll">Satin Doll</a>", by <a href="Duke%20Ellington">Duke Ellington</a>, and the cover art of <a href="Badfinger%20%28album%29">the album "Badfinger"</a> feature a cigarette holder. The video to "<a href="Into%20the%20Great%20Wide%20Open%20%28song%29">Into the Great Wide Open</a>", by <a href="Tom%20Petty%20and%20the%20Heartbreakers">Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers</a>, features Faye Dunaway using her cigarette holder as a <a href="magic%20wand">magic wand</a>.
Rachel Menken, a character on the <a href="AMC%20%28TV%20channel%29">AMC</a> series "<a href="Mad%20Men">Mad Men</a>", smokes cigarettes with a short holder.
